results.title: Quiz show
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Pictures, Michael Jacobs, Julian Krainin, Michael Nozik and Robert Redford
results.brief_description: Ralph Fiennes and John Turturro play contestants battling for huge cash prizes and instant fame on a top-rated quiz show in the mid-1950s. When charges surface that the hit program is fixed and players are being given the answers, it becomes far more than a game. Contestants, producers and the network itself get caught in the centre of an escalating scandal. Nominated for the 1994 Best Picture Academy Award and based on a true story that shocked the United States, this is a very compelling film.

results.title: Quintet
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: Robert Altman’s “Quintet” was received with almost universal derision when it was released in 1979. He had made his reputation with very contemporary, very insisive and very American films. “Quintet” is strikingly different: heavily symbolic, with a mannerist visual palette, it was a departure for Altman and sees him explore themes associated with European existentialism. In a desolate future Ice-Age the remaining inhabitants of Earth are facing their extinction. Paul Newman plays a hunter, returning to his birthplace, accompanied by a pregnant woman (a startling occurrence in a world where most people are no longer able to reproduce). Her murder leads him to a confrontation with the players of Quintet, an elaborate and violent game which is the main activity of the future. As he becomes more involved in the strategies and rules of Quintet, he finds himself losing his identity. This complex and philosophical science-fiction film, creates a future as it may have been envisaged by Kafka and is a uniquely original meditation on the struggle and meaning of human “free will”. Undeniably difficult and ambitious, the film deserves a more serious critical engagement than that offered by contemporary English-language critics. Also stars Vittorio Gassman, Bibi Anderson and Fernando Rey.

results.title: Punch-drunk love = Punch drunk love
results.creator_credit: Columbia, Revolution Studios, New Line Cinema, Joanne Sellar, Daniel Lupi and Paul Thomas Anderson
results.brief_description: This is not a typical Adam Sandler comedy. Barry Egan (Sandler) is a novelty business owner who has seven sisters and is looking for love, (even trying phone sex once) but love finds him, sending his very ordered life upside down. Watching “Punch-drunk love” you find a mix of dark humour and seedy characters, coupled with violent behaviour and social dysfunction - but it’s also a romance with colour, mood and music that carries you along and makes you hope for a happy ending. Written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, winner of Best Director 2002 Cannes Film Festival for this disquieting film. Cast includes Emily Watson, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Luis Guzman.

results.title: Pulp fiction [DVD]
results.creator_credit: A Band Apart, Jersey Films, Miramax Films, Lawrence Bender and Quentin Tarantino
results.brief_description: Tarantino’s amoral black gangster movie pilfers cinematic conventions from a diverse range of sources: from Hong Kong karate cinema to Orson Welles, from Godard’s “Breathless” to B-grade film noir. The mix is intoxicating. Three pulpy stories form the centre of the film. John Travolta plays a mafia hood with a keen addiction to heroin, who is asked to entertain for an evening the girlfriend (Uma Thurman) of his mobster boss; Bruce Willis is an ageing boxer who is asked to throw a fight; and Travolta and Samuel Jackson have to hide the body of a conman they accidentally shot. Surrounding these basic plot contrivances Tarantino creates a charged, constantly shifting narrative that introduces highly eccentric characters drawn from the extremes of popular music, junk and drug culture. The supporting cast is astounding, from Harvey Keitel and Tarantino himself, to Tim Roth and Amanda Plummer’s surreal performance as amphetamine-hyped killers. By introducing peripheral subcultures to the Hollywood mainstream, Tarantino’s film marked a generational shift in American movies. Not the Vietnam generation but the video generation. (Awards: Winner of Palme d’Or, Cannes, 1994).

results.title: Puberty blues [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Limelight Productions, Joan Long, Margaret Kelly and Bruce Beresford
results.brief_description: Unusually, the focus here is on the sexual and social rites of passage of two teenage girls in a male-dominated world. Debbie and Sue are accepted into the Greenhills’ gang, an elite group occupying a particular stretch of Cronulla beach. As surfie groupies Debbie and Sue are required to submit to male whims. Although the girls are proposed as subjects the film maintains a humorously ironic distance from the awfulness of the scene, particularly through the use of narration. The boys, collectively dominant, are individually consigned to the margins. Debbie and Sue are the real mates who ultimately break out of the confines of male-imposed rules. Cast includes: Nell Schofield, Jad Capelja, Geoff Rhoe, Tony Hughes. Based on the book by Kathy Lette and Gabrielle Carey.

results.title: Puberty Blues
results.creator_credit: Limelight Productions, Joan Long, Margaret Kelly and Bruce Beresford
results.brief_description: A popular coming-of-age story set on Cronulla Beach, where two high school girls, Debbie and Sue, have to navigate the chauvinism and sexism of the popular Greenhills surf gang to find their own selves.

results.title: PT 109
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Bryan Foy and Leslie H Martinson
results.brief_description: During the second world war, president to be John Fitzgerald Kennedy took part in the war effort by skippering a PT (Plywood Torpedo) boat in the Solomon Islands. Cliff Robertson enacts these exploits in ‘PT 109’, with a plot that centres around the assignment of harassing the enemy to buy time for a U.S Navy still in development, and a daring rescue by Kennedy to save an injured soldier. Kennedy’s boat - PT 109 , was sliced in half by a Japanese destroyer in August 1943. Lieutenant Kennedy was in the region on a rescue mission to retrieve Marines stranded upon the Isle of Choiseul. It became imperative for him to devise a plan to get his men, and the rescued marines to safety by navigating a safe path through a potentially enemy dominated area. Strangely enough, the successful plan involved a coconut. Cast also includes Ty Hardin, James Gregory, Robert Culp and Grant Williams.

results.title: Psycho (1998) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Image Entertainment, Brian Grazer and Gus Van Sant
results.brief_description: Gus Van Sant’s faithful scene by scene colour ‘recreation’ (the term preferred by the director over ‘remake’) of Hitchcock’s classic thriller about the fate of Marion Crane (Anne Heche in the role made famous by Janet Leigh) who, on-the-run with a large amount of stolen cash, stops at an isolated motel run by Norman Bates (Vince Vaughn) , where she meets an untimely end. Cast also includes Julianne Moore as Marion’s sister and William H. Macy as the private investigator she hires to find her sister.

results.title: Psycho (1960) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Shamley Productions, Paramount Pictures and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: Hitchcock’s macabre masterpiece broke all of the existing rules for horror films and filmmakers, set the standard for a generation of new ones and kept uncounted masses wary of entering showers. It remains a benchmark for the technique of audience manipulation. Undoubtedly Hitchcock’s most calculated work, he was ably supported by the extraordinary leading performances of Anthony Perkins as the psychotic motel owner and Janet Leigh as the hapless thief, reinforced by Bernard Herrmann’s evocatively dissonant musical score. Based on the novel by Robert Bloch.

results.title: Proof (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: House and Moorhouse Films, Lynda House and Jocelyn Moorhouse
results.brief_description: Winner of 7 Australian Film Institute awards, “Proof” is a provocative and engrossing film about a man’s obsessive search for truth. Martin (Hugo Weaving) has been blind from birth. He trusts no-one, except for the camera which has replaced his eyes. His photos are proof that the world he senses is the same as other people see. Then he meets a young kitchen hand, Andy, whose honesty and kindness allow Martin to trust for the first time - until Martin’s jealous housekeeper, Celia, sets out to destroy this relationship. Written and directed by Jocelyn Moorhouse who won a 1992 Victorian Premier’s Literary Award for her screenplay.
